content: Since the 1930s, federal job training and employment programs have aimed to connect vulnerable youth to work and school. These young people are typically low-income with barriers to employment, such as dropping out of school or being in foster care. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 provides job training and related services for unemployed and underemployed individuals, including youth. WIA includes programs for job training, adult education, employment services, and vocational rehabilitation, all authorized under Title I and carried out by the Department of Labor. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 provides job training programs for youth through Title I, administered by the Department of Labor. Programs like WIA Youth Activities, Job Corps, and YouthBuild aim to connect youth to educational and employment opportunities. Despite WIA's authorization expiring in 2003, funding continues through annual appropriations. Policymakers in the 112th Congress hinted at a possible reauthorization of the law. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 provides job training programs for youth through Title I, administered by the Department of Labor. WIA Youth Activities and Job Corps offer job training and employment services for youth. Funding for WIA programs continues through annual appropriations, with potential reauthorization hinted by policymakers in the 112th Congress. Job training and employment services for youth under the Workforce Investment Act (WIA) include WIA Youth Activities, Job Corps, YouthBuild, Reintegration of Ex-Offenders, and Youth Opportunity Grants (YOG). Although WIA's authorization of appropriations expired in FY2003, Congress continues to appropriate funds for these programs. The Youth Opportunity Grants (YOG) program, funded through FY2003, created centers in low-income communities for youth employment and services. Congress continues to appropriate funds for youth job training programs, except for YOG which has not been funded since FY2003. Various programs under the Division of Youth Services in DOL's Employment and Training Administration connect low-income youth to educational and employment opportunities. The Youth Opportunity Grants program, along with Job Corps, YouthBuild, and the youth component of the Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program, aim to connect low-income youth to educational and employment opportunities. Each program serves youth with specific employment barriers, with YouthBuild specifically for high school dropouts. The programs provide employment and educational services differently, with Youth Activities requiring specific elements like mentoring, while YouthBuild focuses on housing-related activities. The Youth Activities program, YouthBuild, Job Corps, and the youth component of the Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program offer various services to low-income youth. Each program has specific elements and focuses on different activities, such as mentoring, construction work, residential services, and reentry services. Funding for these programs is allocated differently, with DOL distributing funds to local WIBs for Youth Activities and entering agreements with organizations to operate Job Corps centers. DOL funds Youth Activities through states and local WIBs, operates Job Corps centers through agreements with organizations, and collaborates with USDA for Job Corps programs on USDA lands. YouthBuild and Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program award grants competitively. Congress is working on reauthorizing WIA. The House Education and Workforce Committee also played a role in the reauthorization process.
